sentences.text: Federal elections were held in Belgium on 9 June 2024. The Chamber of Representatives (Belgium)|Chamber of Representatives received 150 members with five-year terms. 2024 European Parliament election in Belgium|European and 2024 Belgian regional elections|regional elections took place 2024 Belgian elections|on the same day.

sentences.text: The 150 members of the Chamber of Representatives (Belgium)|Chamber of Representatives are elected in 11 multi-member Constituencies of Belgium|constituencies, being the ten Provinces of Belgium|provinces and Brussels, with between 4 and 24 seats. Seats are allocated using the D'Hondt method, with an electoral threshold of 5% per constituency.{{sfn|Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights|2024|p=5}}

references.text: <ref name=odihr4>{{cite report |author=Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights |date=23-26 January 2024 |title=Federal Elections, 9 June 2024 |url=https://www.osce.org/files/f/documents/7/1/569376.pdf |page=4 |access-date=11 June 2024 |archive-date=9 June 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240609022113/https://www.osce.org/files/f/documents/7/1/569376.pdf |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: The 87 representatives elected from the five Flemish Region provinces, Antwerp (Chamber of Representatives constituency)|Antwerp (24), East Flanders (Chamber of Representatives constituency)|East Flanders (20), Flemish Brabant (Chamber of Representatives constituency)|Flemish Brabant (15), Limburg (Chamber of Representatives constituency)|Limburg (12) and West Flanders (Chamber of Representatives constituency)|West Flanders (16), automatically belonged to the Dutch-speaking language group in parliament, whereas those 47 elected from the five provinces of Wallonia, Hainaut (Chamber of Representatives constituency)|Hainaut (17), Liège (Chamber of Representatives constituency)|Liège (14), Luxembourg (Chamber of Representatives constituency)|Luxembourg (4), Namur (Chamber of Representatives constituency)|Namur (7) and Walloon Brabant (Chamber of Representatives constituency)|Walloon Brabant (5), formed the French-speaking language group. The 16 members elected in Brussels (Chamber of Representatives constituency)|Brussels can choose to join either group. Apportionment of seats is done every ten years in accordance with population data, last by royal order in 2022, when Brussels and Namur each gained a seat while Hainaut and Liège lost a seat.

sentences.text:
Hainaut will feature three party chairmen (Bouchez for MR, Magnette for PS and Nollet for Ecolo) as well as popular ex-MR ex-minister Crucke for Les Engagés. In Namur, three federal deputy prime ministers will run against each other (Dermagne for PS, Gilkinet for Ecolo and Clarinval for MR). The right-wing Flemish nationalist N-VA party is also fielding candidates in Wallonia for the first time.

sentences.text: In the run up to the 2024 Belgian federal election, various organisations carried out opinion polling to gauge voting intentions in Belgium. The date range for these polls were from a few months after the 2019 Belgian federal election, held on 25 May 2019, to shortly before the 2024 Belgian federal election. The results of nationwide polls were usually numerically split into the three Communities, regions, and language areas of Belgium|Belgian regions: Flanders, Brussels and Wallonia. The federal election was part of a 2024 Belgian elections|group of elections which also included the 2024 Belgian regional elections|regional elections and the 2024 European Parliament election in Belgium|European elections. Some polls might have undefined voting intentions without differentiating between the elections.{{citation needed|date=June 2024}}

sentences.text: Since the Sixth Belgian state reform|sixth state reform of 2011, the Senate (Belgium)|Senate is no longer directly elected. The regional parliaments elect 50 senators based on the results of the concurrent regional elections (the Flemish Parliament elects 29, the Parliament of the French Community elects ten, the Walloon Parliament elects eight, the Parliament of the Brussels-Capital Region elects two Francophone senators and the Parliament of the German-speaking Community elects one). The elected senators in turn Co-option|co-opt 10 senators (six Dutch-speaking and four Francophone), who are allocated based on the preceding election results of the Chamber of Representatives, making a total of 60 senators.

sentences.text: The New Flemish Alliance's (N-VA) Bart De Wever claimed victory. Even though Vlaams Belang came second, its leader Tom Van Grieken expressed disappointment, as the party was expected to overtake N-VA to become the biggest in Flanders. In Wallonia, Reformist Movement's (MR) president Georges-Louis Bouchez emphasized the electorate's willingness for change, after his party gained more votes than PS for the first time in decades.

references.text: <ref name="guardian">{{Cite news |title=Belgium headed for new government as PM set to resign after general election |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/article/2024/jun/10/belgium-general-election-2024-pm-prime-minister-alexander-de-croo-set-to-resign |access-date=10 June 2024 |website=The Guardian |language=en |last1=O'Carroll |first1=Lisa |archive-date=10 June 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240610174551/https://www.theguardian.com/world/article/2024/jun/10/belgium-general-election-2024-pm-prime-minister-alexander-de-croo-set-to-resign |url-status=live }}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite news |title=Belgium drifts to the right — but not far right |last1=Haeck |first1=Pieter |last2=Gijs |first2=Camille |last3=Jack |first3=Victor |url=https://www.politico.eu/article/belgium-far-right-election-extremist-landslide-elections-in-europe-results-2024/ |date=9 June 2024 |access-date=11 June 2024 |archive-date=10 June 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240610181057/https://www.politico.eu/article/belgium-far-right-election-extremist-landslide-elections-in-europe-results-2024/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: According to political analysts, the most obvious federal coalition would consist of the right-wing N-VA and MR, and centre-left Vooruit, with the centrist CD&V and Les Engagés parties to reach at least 76 seats. Other coalitions are ruled out, following the decision of Open Vld and PS to be part of the opposition. Vlaams Belang is not expected to be part of the government at any level, due to the cordon sanitaire (politics)|cordon sanitaire.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite news |title=Long road ahead or quick decisions: What possible coalitions can be formed? |last=Walker |first=Lauren |url=https://www.brusselstimes.com/belgian-elections-2024/1085844/long-road-ahead-for-belgium-what-possible-coalitions-can-be-formed |date=10 June 2024 |access-date=11 June 2024 |archive-date=10 June 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240610210027/https://www.brusselstimes.com/belgian-elections-2024/1085844/long-road-ahead-for-belgium-what-possible-coalitions-can-be-formed |url-status=live }}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite news |title="Federal coalition puzzle can be solved quickly, but N-VA will have to make choices" |url=https://www.vrt.be/vrtnws/en/2024/06/11/_federal-coalition-puzzle-can-be-solved-quickly-but-n-va-will-h/ |date=11 June 2024 |access-date=11 June 2024 |archive-date=12 June 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240612024042/https://www.vrt.be/vrtnws/en/2024/06/11/_federal-coalition-puzzle-can-be-solved-quickly-but-n-va-will-h/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: Exploratory coalition talks started on 10 June, the day after the elections. As is tradition, party leaders are individually invited to an audience with the King, starting with the biggest parties. On 11 June, the MR and Les Engagés announced a preliminary agreement to form a government in the Walloon parliament, following the 2024 Belgian regional elections|regional elections. As part of the agreement, the two parties would form a partnership during government formation talks at the federal level.

sentences.text: On 31 January 2025, a governmental agreement was reached between the Arizona parties, with De Wever being sworn in as prime minister on 3 February 2025.
